title: Prayer and worship of the believer

children.title: prayer
children.comment: Fellowship with God through Jesus Christ, expressed in adoration, thanksgiving and intercession, through which believers draw near to God and learn more of his will for their lives. Scripture stresses the vital role of the Holy Spirit in stimulating and guiding prayer.

children.title: prayer, as a relationship with God
children.comment: Prayer is based on God's love for believers. Through his grace, he gives them things which they do not deserve, while through his mercy he shields them from those things which they do deserve.

children.title: God's children can turn to their Father in prayer
Jesus Christ's prayer life with his Father
It is possible to approach God in prayer because of Jesus Christ's sacrifice
Prayer reflects a longing after God
prayer, as a response to God
children.comment: Prayer offers believers a means of acknowledging the character and purposes of God and the opportunity to seek guidance concerning his will for them.

children.title: The direction of prayer is upwards towards God

seealsos.comment: Nehemiah felt so close to God that it was automatic for him to speak to God and the king almost simultaneously

children.title: Contemplative prayer as a response to God's presence
Prayer of acceptance in response to God's call
In response to sin being exposed
Prayer of co-operation in response to God's purposes
Prayer of confidence in response to God's mercy and grace
prayer, and God's will
children.comment: Prayer is concerned not only with the well-being of the one who prays. A vital aspect of its purpose is to allow the will of God to be done, and to bring glory and honour to his name.

children.title: The desire that God's name be honoured
The desire that God's will be fulfilled

seealsos.comment: Submission to God's will characterised Jesus Christ's prayer life.

children.title: God answers prayer that accords with his will
Petitioners may enquire of God to discover his will
The Holy Spirit helps believers to pray in God's will
God's response to prayers allows believers to discern his will
God does not respond to the prayers of the wicked
prayer, God's promises concerning
children.comment: God promises to hear and respond to the prayers of his people, when they pray in the name of his Son and according to his will.

children.title: God expects his people to make requests of him in prayer
God promises to answer prayer in the name of Jesus Christ
God promises to respond to the prayers of his people in times of need
God promises to hear the prayers of the oppressed
God promises to hear the prayers of the truly penitent
God promises to hear the prayers of his obedient people
The need in prayer to have confidence in God's promises
prayer, and worship
children.comment: Worship is turning to God in awe, praise and joy, as his people realise how wonderful he is. Prayer is a natural part of worship: to know God is to want to worship him and pray to him.

children.title: Worship is a fundamental requirement of life
All nations are exhorted to worship God
Israel is commanded to worship God
Right attitudes in worship are imperative
Reverence and humility characterise acceptable worship
Honesty, without hypocrisy, characterises acceptable worship
Prayer can focus on different aspects of God's character
Prayer can focus on God's holiness
Prayer can focus on God's glory
Prayer can focus on God's majesty
Prayer can focus on God's kingship
Prayer can focus on God's love and compassion
Prayer can focus on God's justice and righteousness
Prayer can focus on God's creative activity
prayer, as praise and thanksgiving
children.comment: Prayer embraces praising God for who he is, thanking him for what he has already done, and looking forward with joy to what he has promised to do in the future.

children.title: Scripture exhorts God's people to praise and thank him
Praise and thanksgiving in prayer for God's goodness towards his people
Praise and thanksgiving for deliverance and salvation
Praise and thanksgiving for provision of material needs
Praise and thanksgiving for help in time of trouble
Praise and thanksgiving for the encouragement of other believers
Notable songs of praise and thanksgiving

secondaryrefs.comment: Moses, on crossing the Red Sea
David, on bringing the ark to Jerusalem
Mary, on learning that she was to be the mother of Jesus Christ

children.title: prayer, as asking God
children.comment: God wants his people to turn to him in prayer, individually and corporately, in times of need or crisis, and to bring requests to him as a Father.

children.title: God's people are commanded to bring their requests to him
Prayers of individuals in time of crisis
Individual petition to God in prayer
Individual prayer for the birth of a child
Corporate prayer for protection, especially at times of crisis
The first Christians prayed together when they met
The first Christians prayed together at times of crisis or important decisions
When Barnabas and Saul were sent off by the church at Antioch
When Paul and Silas experienced persecution
prayer, for others
children.comment: Believers should pray, not only for their own needs, but for those of others. Scripture provides many examples of intercession, and commends it as pleasing to God.

primaryrefs.comment: God forbade the prophet Jeremiah to pray for his people because they were unrepentant sinners.

children.title: The Holy Spirit intercedes for believers
Christians are to intercede for others
Christians are to pray for their enemies
Christians are to pray for one another
Christians are to prayer for rulers
Examples of pleas made to Jesus Christ on behalf of others
Examples of notable prayers of intercession

secondaryrefs.comment: Hezekiah for deliverance
Ezra for a safe journey
Daniel for Jerusalem
Jesus Christ for his disciples
Paul for the believers in Colosse

children.title: prayer, and faith
children.comment: Effective prayer depends on faith, especially on a willingness to trust in God's faithfulness to his promises to his people.

children.title: Faith is necessary in order to approach God
Faith is necessary to receive benefits from God
Faith is necessary for effective prayer
Jesus Christ responded to people's need on the basis of faith
Examples of notable prayers of faith

secondaryrefs.comment: Elijah, in contest with the prophets of Baal
Elijah, praying about rain
Elijah and the widow's son
Elisha and the Shunammite's son

children.title: prayer, persistence in
children.comment: An answer to prayer may not come immediately. Petitioners are to continue praying earnestly. This requires patience, determination and, at times, a willingness to wrestle with God for the desired outcome.

children.title: The principle of persistence in prayer
Prayer should be made with patience and perseverance
Jesus Christ taught his disciples to persist in prayer
Persistence in prayer was exemplified in the early church
Paul exhorted the churches to practise persistent prayer
Jacob persists in wrestling with God
Moses persists in interceding for Israel
Hannah persistently asks for a son
Elijah persists in prayer about the rain
The psalmists persist in calling out to God
Jesus Christ persisted in pursuing the Father's will
Persistence in prayer is exemplified in waiting for God
prayer, answers to
children.comment: God has promised to answer prayer for personal or corporate needs and for the needs of others.

children.title: God answers the prayers of individuals
God answers Hannah's prayer for a son
God answers the prayers of the prophets
God answers the prayers of the kings of Israel
Answered prayer for deliverance from hardship
Answered prayer for deliverance from enemies
God answers the prayer of the oppressed
prayer, doubts about
children.comment: Sometimes God does not seem to answer prayer, causing his people to doubt him. Scripture affirms God's faithfulness to those who pray according to his will, and points out that the human understanding of a situation is limited.

children.title: Examples of God's servants questioning his promises
Examples of God's servants questioning the tasks he has given them
Examples of God's servants expressing their anger and confusion in prayer
God's response to prayers of questioning or complaint
God reiterates his promises to those who question him
God provides help for those who question him
God rebukes those who question him
God explains events to those who question him
prayerlessness
children.comment: Without prayer any relationship with God is impoverished because vital communication is lost.

children.title: Guilt as a result of disobedience

secondaryrefs.comment: Adam and Eve did not respond to their sin by praying. On the contrary they sought to hide from God
Jonah tried to run away from God.
Joshua devised his own plan in attacking Ai and did not seek the LORD until after he suffered a disastrous defeat.

primaryrefs.comment: This verse implies that prayer involves effort--the people only paid lip service to God.

children.title: Israel trusts in other people rather than God
Israel's failure to repent of their sins
The lack of an intercessor among God's people

primaryrefs.comment: Peter had previously failed to pray in Gethsemane.

secondaryrefs.comment: This literally means they had no fellowship with the LORD

children.title: Conflicts with others because of unfulfilled desires
prayer, advice for effective
children.comment: Scripture provides guidance concerning what attitudes and actions are appropriate for effective prayer. It also identifies a number of motives which are likely to lead to prayers being unanswered.

children.title: Qualities that lead to effective prayer
prayerfulness
children.comment: An attitude by which a constant relationship between God and believers is developed.

children.title: Prayerfulness is a way of life
Prayerfulness arises from a desire to be with God
Prayerfulness arises from an awareness of need that can only be met by God
Prayerfulness demonstrates a continuing trust in God
Prayerfulness involves a heart that is right with God
Prayerfulness involves the need to be alert
Prayerfulness needs to be maintained especially in difficult circumstances
Examples of people whose prayerfulness proved effective
Hannah, who prayed for a child
Elijah, an ordinary man who prayed
Nehemiah, a man who discovered God's plan through prayer
Daniel, whose patience in prayer was rewarded
Jesus Christ, who perfectly trusted his Father
The early church, which was founded upon prayer
Paul, who prayed for all the churches which he founded or visited
prayer, in the church
children.comment: The prayer life of the NT provides a pattern from which the modern church can learn, both in terms of the importance of prayer, and also matters for prayer.

children.title: Prayer was at the centre of the life of the early church
They prayed when they met together
They prayed about the selection and ordination of Christian leaders
The apostles' teaching on prayer in church life
Prayer for the spread of the gospel
Prayer was central to their ministry
prayer, practicalities of
children.comment: Scripture commends a life of prayer, characterised by simplicity of expression, sincerity of heart and trust in the promises of God.  It gives guidance on how, when and where to pray.

children.title: Scripture stresses the importance of prayer
Judgment comes on those who do not pray
Prayer can be offered at any time
Prayer is not confined to any single place
Prayer may be accompanied by fasting
prayer, as a relationship with God
children.comment: Prayer is based on God's love for believers. Through his grace, he gives them things which they do not deserve, while through his mercy he shields them from those things which they do deserve.

children.title: God's children can turn to their Father in prayer
Jesus Christ's prayer life with his Father
It is possible to approach God in prayer because of Jesus Christ's sacrifice
Prayer reflects a longing after God

children.title: Scripture stresses the importance of prayer
Judgment comes on those who do not pray
Prayer can be offered at any time
Prayer is not confined to any single place
Prayer may be accompanied by fasting
worship
children.comment: The praise, adoration and reverence of God, both in public and private. It is a celebration of the worthiness of God, by which honour is given to his name.

children.title: worship, of God alone
children.comment: God alone is worthy of worship; the worship of other gods is forbidden. In the NT worship is offered to the Son of God.

children.title: God alone is to be worshipped
He alone is worthy of worship

primaryrefs.comment: The English word ``worship'' means literally ``worth-ship''.

children.title: The worship of God the Father
The worship of God the Son
The worship of other gods forbidden
worship, reasons for
children.comment: The supreme reason for human existence is to worship God for his love, greatness and saving deeds.

children.title: To worship is a divine command
God's people are to be a worshipping people
Worship is the response of God's people

primaryrefs.comment: Noah's response to God's deliverance from the flood.

seealsos.comment: God's promise of an inheritance to Abraham
God's deliverance of Daniel in Babylon
the healing of the paralytic
the healing of the crippled beggar

children.title: worship, acceptable attitudes in
children.comment: True worship is not the mechanical repetition of rituals, but should be wholehearted and reverent. It should be based upon trustful and obedient lives, in that obedience is itself to be seen as an act of worship.

children.title: Worship should be in accordance with God's commands
Worship should give God the honour due to him
Worship of mere human devising is unacceptable
Worship should be orderly and reverent
Worship should be grounded in godly and obedient living
worship, places of
children.comment: Under the old covenant, there were rules governing the places where worship might be offered but under the new covenant the earthly location is of no importance.

children.title: Worship at places commemorating some act of God
Worship at a place chosen by God
Worship at the Tent of Meeting
Worship at the temple in Jerusalem
The earthly location for worship is unimportant
worship, elements of
children.comment: Praise and thankfulness are important elements of worship, which also includes confession of sin, the reading of Scripture and music.

children.title: Worship includes the confession of Jesus Christ as Lord
Worship includes the reading of God's word
worship, hindrances to
children.comment: True worship goes beyond mere form and can therefore be hindered by a wrong relationship to God or to others.

children.title: Worship that is merely formal is unacceptable
Worship is hindered by wrong relationships
worship, times for
children.comment: Scripture stresses the importance of regular worship, while at the same time recognising that believers may worship God spontaneously.

children.title: At the three annual pilgrim festivals
In response to an awareness of the closeness of God
In response to the experience of God's mercy
In response to the presence and power of Jesus Christ
Worship should not be dependent on circumstances
The continuous worship of God in heaven
worship, results of
children.comment: Worship not only gives God what is due to him but also results in many benefits for his people.

children.title: True worship brings benefits for God's people
A deeper sense of Jesus Christ's lordship
worship, of God alone
children.comment: God alone is worthy of worship; the worship of other gods is forbidden. In the NT worship is offered to the Son of God.

children.title: God alone is to be worshipped
He alone is worthy of worship

primaryrefs.comment: The English word ``worship'' means literally ``worth-ship''.

children.title: The worship of God the Father
The worship of God the Son
The worship of other gods forbidden

children.title: True worship brings benefits for God's people
A deeper sense of Jesus Christ's lordship
adoration
children.comment: An attitude of worship characterised by love and reverence towards God. It can also describe the love between man and woman.

cschildren.title: Adoration of God by his people
Examples of adoration in worship

secondaryrefs.comment: Hannah
David
Solomon
Mary

cschildren.title: Adoration also describes the love between man and woman

children.title: amen
children.comment: A Hebrew term expressing the ideas of truth and reliability, often used in prayer and adoration.

cschildren.title: Amen as an expression of worship

seealsos.comment: The repetition of ``Amen'' here conveys Ezra's intensity of feeling as he read the Book of the Law. The response of the people represents a solemn, formal acceptance of God's commandments
``Amen'' can mean either ``Yes indeed, it is so'' or ``So be it''
the worship of heaven

cschildren.title: Amen confirms a grace or blessing
Amen confirms a vow or action
Amen as a title of Jesus Christ

seealsos.comment: The implication is that all God's promises find their fulfilment in Jesus Christ.

children.title: asking
children.comment: The act of making requests of another, as an expression of dependence. Scripture encourages believers to ask things of God in prayer, and gives guidance concerning the motivation in doing so.

cschildren.title: Asking as an aspect of human relationships

seealsos.comment: The people asked for a king
the Magi seek the king of the Jews
Jesus Christ asks questions in the temple

cschildren.title: Asking as an aspect of prayer

children.title: Frequent requests for guidance or insight

cschildren.title: The grounds for asking

children.title: In the name of Jesus Christ
benedictions
children.comment: Prayers invoking God's blessing upon others. They are often spoken at a time of impending separation, although they may sometimes constitute greetings.

cschildren.title: Benedictions pronounced by priests
Benedictions pronounced by kings
Benedictions pronounced by other leaders of the nation of Israel
Benedictions pronounced by family members
Apostolic benedictions on the church

children.title: The blessing of grace and peace
The blessing of God in all his fulness
calling upon God
children.comment: Asking God to act, in dependence upon him and out of a sense of sometimes desperate need.

cschildren.title: Calling upon God as an act of worship

children.title: By those who depend upon him and proclaim his name
Those who do not acknowledge God or call upon his name

cschildren.title: Calling upon God in time of need
Calling upon God for his salvation
Calling upon God was part of the priestly function of intercession
Examples of those who called upon God

children.title: celebration
children.comment: Although there are examples of private celebrations in Scripture, most celebration is associated with the acts of God. The enemies of God's people also celebrate, but in the end it is the triumph of God's purpose that is celebrated.

cschildren.title: Celebrations in everyday life

secondaryrefs.comment: birthday
for an honoured guest
family reunion

cschildren.title: The Israelites celebrated God's acts

children.title: Celebrating God's gifts of harvest: Pentecost and Tabernacles
Celebrating their deliverance from slavery in Egypt: Passover
Celebrating the deliverance of the nation through Esther: Purim

cschildren.title: Religious celebrations

children.title: The bringing of the ark of the covenant to Jerusalem
The bringing of the ark of the covenant to the temple
The completion and dedication of the first temple
The dedication of the second temple
The reading of the law after the building of the walls of Jersualem
Christians celebrate the death of Christ and his return

cschildren.title: The enemies of God's people celebrate

secondaryrefs.comment: capture of Samson
Belshazzar's feast

cschildren.title: Celebration in heaven

children.title: The final triumph of Jesus Christ
commemoration
children.comment: The act of remembering particular people, places or events in order to reflect on and be thankful for God's faithfulness.

cschildren.title: Commemoration of people
Commemoration of places
Commemoration of events

children.title: Commemoration of God's creation of the world
Commemoration of God's acts in history
Commemoration of God's provision of food
doxology
children.comment: A form of words that offers praise to God, especially for his work of creation and redemption. Scripture records a number of these forms of praise which were used in both public and private worship.

cschildren.title: Doxologies used in the formal worship of Israel
Doxologies used in the spontaneous praise of God's people
Doxologies used as a benediction
Doxologies used in heavenly worship

children.title: enquiring of God
children.comment: Requesting from God a definite direct response to a particular question. In the OT, people are frequently said to enquire of God for knowledge or guidance, often through the intermediacy of a priest or prophet.

cschildren.title: Enquiring of God for knowledge
Enquiring of God for guidance
Enquiring of God through intermediaries
Enquiring of God by casting lots

seealsos.comment: The Urim and Thummim were sacred lots carried in the breastpiece of the High Priest's ephod

cschildren.title: Enquiring of God in prayer
Enquiring of God at the tabernacle
Devotion to God as a necessary prerequisite for enquiring of him
Failure to enquire of God displeases him and heralds disaster
The Holy Spirit and enquiring of God

children.title: hands, lifting up of
children.comment: A human gesture which can be a sign of worship and adoration or indicate the swearing of a solemn oath. God is portrayed as raising his hands as a sign of authority over his creation.

cschildren.title: God's uplifted hand

children.title: God's uplifted hand signifies his power
God's uplifted hand signifies his judgment

cschildren.title: Hands uplifted for swearing oaths

children.title: Oaths taken by people and angels

cschildren.title: Hands uplifted in worship
Hands lifted up for blessing
Hands lifted up as a threat
Uplifted hands as a sign of minimal effort
Uplifted hands as a sign of support

children.title: importunity
children.comment: Persistence and boldness in making requests to God in prayer and to other people, and persevering until a favourable response is received.

children.title: importunity, towards God
children.comment: Earnestness and perseverance in presenting requests to God on behalf of oneself and others; seen in persistent pleading, faithful intercession and bold appeal.

children.title: Further examples of importunity in prayer

secondaryrefs.comment: Abraham prays for Sodom
Gideon asks for assurance
a Canaanite woman begs for Jesus Christ's help
Blind men call out to Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ prays in Gethsemane
Legion begs for mercy
Paul pleads with God to take away his ``thorn''.

children.title: Further examples of perseverance in prayer

secondaryrefs.comment: Jacob wrestles with God
Moses fasts and prays because of Israel's sin
David pleads for his sick child
The prophets of Baal appeal unsuccessfully to their god
Nehemiah prays for God's people
Daniel waits for the interpretation of his vision
Anna looks for God to redeem his people.

children.title: Further examples of earnestness in prayer

secondaryrefs.comment: Hannah prays for a child
Solomon prays at the dedication of the Temple
Elijah prays for rain to cease
Ezra prays about the people's sin
Hezekiah prays for healing
Daniel prays for Jerusalem
Jairus asks Jesus Christ to heal his daughter
A nobleman begs Jesus Christ to heal his son
The early church prays for Peter's release from prison.

children.title: importunity, towards people
children.comment: Boldness, urgency and persistence in appealing to others; seen in making requests of all kinds, presenting the gospel and giving Christian instruction; seen too in God's patient and persistent pleading with people.

secondaryrefs.comment: Lot prevails on his angelic visitors to stay with him
Potiphar's wife propositions Joseph
Balak summons Balaam
Samson's wife presses for the answer to his riddle
Delilah nags Samson to know the secret of his strength
Elisha is requested to authorise a search for Elijah
Royal officials plead with Mordecai
Esther pleads with the king
A poor man pleads in vain with fair-weather friends
Jeremiah pleads with King Zedekiah
The crowds call for Jesus Christ to be crucified
Peter knocks on the door after his release from prison
The chief priests urge that Paul be taken to Jerusalem
The Macedonian churches ask to share in the giving to God's people
Paul pleads with Euodia and Syntyche to agree.

children.title: God's appeal to his wayward people

primaryrefs.comment: Finally, God sends his Son.

children.title: longing for God
children.comment: A deep desire for God, which Scripture often compares to hunger or thirst. Only Jesus Christ can truly satisfy this longing for God.

cschildren.title: The individual's longing for God
The longing for God compared to hunger and thirst
The longing for God is satisfied through Jesus Christ

children.title: Lord's Prayer, the
children.comment: The name given to the prayer Jesus Christ taught his disciples, probably as a model prayer for regular use.

cschildren.title: Aspects of the Lord's Prayer

children.title: A recognition of God as Father and Lord
A desire for God's perfect will to be done

primaryrefs.comment: NIV footnote.

children.title: magnifying God
children.comment: Giving glory to God through worship and through upright living. God's people are exhorted to praise him and to bring honour to his name.

cschildren.title: Ways of magnifying God

children.title: meditation
children.comment: Spending time in quietness and usually alone, drawing close to God and listening to him, pondering on his word, his creation, his mighty works or other aspects of his self-revelation.

cschildren.title: The importance of meditation
Meditation on the person of God
Meditation on God's word
Meditation on the works of God
Meditation on the creation
Meditation at night
Examples of people meditating

seealsos.comment: Eliphaz' advice to Job
Mary
the Ethiopian eunuch

cschildren.title: The results of meditation

children.title: praise
children.comment: The celebration, honouring and adoration of God, in the power of the Holy Spirit, whether by individual believers or communities of believers.

children.title: praise, reasons for
children.comment: Scripture treats praise as the natural response of believers to God's person and actions.

children.title: Praise is commanded of God's people
Praise is due to God alone
Praise as an act of witness
Praise in response to God's nature
Praise in response to God's deeds
For sending his Son, Jesus Christ
praise, manner and methods of
children.comment: Praise is the natural response of believers to God at all times and in all places, involving adoration in music and song. God himself assists believers to praise him through his Spirit.

children.title: God is praised through Jesus Christ
God can be praised at any time and in any place
God helps believers to praise him
The Holy Spirit moves believers to praise
Hallelujah as a frequent expression of praise to God

primaryrefs.comment: ``Hallelujah'' translates ``praise the LORD''.

children.title: Praise for his election of Israel
Hosanna as an acclamation of praise

primaryrefs.comment: ``Hosanna'' is the Greek form of the Hebrew term seeking God's salvation.

children.title: Following the assurance of answered prayer

primaryrefs.comment: There are a number of possible ways of understanding this obscure term: pausing or lifting up, perhaps indicating that the singers or musicians should sing or play ``forte''.

children.title: After a statement comparing God's greatness with human insignificance
After an affirmation of security in God
praise, examples of
children.comment: Scripture provides many examples of individuals who praised God. These examples illustrate the variety of ways and methods in which God can be praised, as well as the motivation for that praise.

children.title: OT examples of those who praised God
NT examples of those who praised God
Those who were healed by Jesus Christ

remembering
children.comment: The process of recalling the past, especially the presence and activity of God in the history of his people. Remembering God's work in the past can lead to praise and rejoicing, and to hope for the future. God himself remembers.

cschildren.title: Divine remembering

children.title: Situations in which God will not remember

cschildren.title: The Holy Spirit helps believers to remember Jesus Christ and his words
Human remembering

children.title: Believers are to remember God's person
Believers are to remember God's acts in the past
Believers are to remember God's wrath
Believers are to remember God's commands
Believers are to remember their responsibilities towards one another
Believers are to remember the death of Jesus Christ

cschildren.title: The importance of remembering

children.title: Remembering should produce hope for the future
striving with God
children.comment: Striving with God can refer both to the fruitless opposition of the ungodly to God's will and purposes, and to the struggle of the righteous with God, as they seek to find his will and obey it.

cschildren.title: The striving of the wicked with God

children.title: It is the result of a guilty conscience
It leads to the destruction of those who attempt it

cschildren.title: Ways in which the wicked strive with God

primaryrefs.comment: To attack God's people is to attempt to attack God himself.

cschildren.title: Jacob strives with God

primaryrefs.comment: Jacob's struggle with God represents the conflict within himself between self-will and dependence on God. As ``Jacob'', the supplanter, he had overcome Esau and Laban, but God demonstrates his superior power in the wrestling match so that as ``Israel'' he will be submissive to the divine will.

cschildren.title: The striving of the righteous with God

children.title: The struggle to understand God's purposes
study
children.comment: The application of the mind with a view to acquiring knowledge, particularly of the Scriptures. God promises his help to those who give themselves to this work.

cschildren.title: The study of the works of the LORD

primaryrefs.comment: The works mentioned are his acts of providence and grace.

cschildren.title: God's people are to study in order to gain wisdom
The study of human activity, achievement and wisdom

seealsos.comment: The Teacher turned from human wisdom to searching out and setting forth proverbs
He concluded that all human study was wearisome.

cschildren.title: The study of the word of God

children.title: The study of the word of God is commended
Ezra studied the law of the LORD
Some Jews studied the Scriptures without finding Jesus Christ

cschildren.title: God promises his help in the study of the Scriptures

children.title: thanksgiving
children.comment: The offering of thanks, especially for gifts received. Scripture emphasises the importance of giving thanks to God for all his gifts and works, both as an expression of our dependence upon him and gratitude to him.

cschildren.title: Thanksgiving is sometimes linked with praise to God
The duty of thanksgiving to God
The expression of thanksgiving to God
Believers are to give thanks in all circumstances
Thanksgiving for the blessings of salvation

seealsos.comment: for victory through Christ
for God's grace
for Jesus Christ himself
for union with Christ

cschildren.title: Examples of those who gave thanks to God

children.title: waiting on God
children.comment: Being prepared to patiently look towards God for his guidance and accepting the timing he proposes. Waiting on God can lead to an atmosphere of expectation and confidence in God and a realisation of the unreliability of one's own judgment.

cschildren.title: Waiting on God is something that is commanded
Reasons for waiting on God

secondaryrefs.comment: for his providence
for his salvation
for his blessings

cschildren.title: Waiting on Christ

primaryrefs.comment: ``Waiting on Christ'' is often seen in terms of waiting patiently for God to bring about the end of all things through the promised second coming of Jesus Christ.

cschildren.title: The benefits of waiting on God
Examples of people who waited on God

secondaryrefs.comment: Jacob
David
Isaiah
Micah
Joseph of Arimathea
Simeon
